verses.text: Then Elihu answered and said:
verses.comment: Elihu continues his response to Job and his friends. Unlike the previous speakers, he claims to speak with wisdom from God.

verses.text: Hear my words, you wise men, and listen to me, you who know.
verses.comment: Elihu appeals to the wisdom of his audience, emphasizing discernment, which is also a New Testament exhortation (see Heb. 5:14).

verses.text: For the ear tests words as the mouth tastes food.
verses.comment: The ability to judge truth is likened to tasting food, a theme echoed in Proverbs (Prov. 2:9).

verses.text: Let us discern for ourselves what is right; let us know among ourselves what is good.
verses.comment: This verse encourages moral discernment, a responsibility for all believers (see Heb. 13:18).

verses.text: For Job has said, 'I am righteous, and God has taken away my justice.'
verses.comment: Elihu summarizes Job’s complaint, setting up to challenge Job’s perception of God's justice.

verses.text: Should I lie against my right? My wound is incurable, though I am without transgression.'
verses.comment: Elihu refers to Job's claim that his suffering is undeserved, prompting a reflection on human understanding of suffering.

verses.text: What man is like Job, who drinks up scorn like water,
verses.comment: Elihu uses a simile for Job’s outspokenness. The phrase 'drinks up scorn like water' suggests familiarity with hardship and suffering.

verses.text: Who goes in company with evildoers and walks with wicked men?
verses.comment: Elihu accuses Job of aligning himself with the complaints of the wicked, thus exaggerating Job’s position.

verses.text: For he has said, 'It profits a man nothing that he should delight himself in God.'
verses.comment: Elihu claims Job’s words undermine piety, highlighting a key theme: the necessity of trusting in God's goodness even during suffering.

verses.text: Therefore, listen to me, you men of understanding: Far be it from God to do wickedness, and from the Almighty to do wrong.
verses.comment: Here, Elihu asserts the perfect righteousness of God, reinforcing the doctrine that God is incapable of injustice (cf. Rom. 9:14).

verses.text: For he will repay man according to his work, and everyone will receive according to his ways.
verses.comment: The principle of retribution, evident here, connects to New Testament teachings on judgment according to works (Matt. 16:27).

verses.text: Truly, God will not do wickedly, and the Almighty will not pervert justice.
verses.comment: God's perfect justice is a repeated theme—it challenges believers to trust God’s providence even when events seem unjust.

verses.text: Who gave him charge over the earth? Or who appointed him over the whole world?
verses.comment: Creation belongs to God alone, echoing Genesis 1:1 and emphasizing His sovereignty—a concept deepened in the New Testament teaching of Christ’s lordship over all (see Col. 1:16).

verses.text: If he should set his heart on man, if he should gather to himself his spirit and his breath,
verses.comment: This verse references the creation account, emphasizing dependence on God’s Spirit for life.

verses.text: All flesh would perish together, and man would return to dust.
verses.comment: Echoes of Genesis are found here: humans return to dust, highlighting the mortality and dependency of man—themes present in both Old and New Testaments.

verses.text: If you have understanding, hear this; listen to what I say.
verses.comment: A renewed call for attention to wisdom. Compare also Jesus’ teaching to hear and understand in Matt. 13:9.

verses.text: Shall one who hates justice govern? Will you condemn the righteous and mighty One?
verses.comment: Raises rhetorical questions concerning God’s governance: only one who is just is fit to rule.

verses.text: Who says to a king, 'You are worthless,' or to nobles, 'You are wicked'?
verses.comment: Elihu notes the impropriety of challenging divinely instituted authority—an idea later seen in Rom. 13:1.

verses.text: Who shows no partiality to princes nor regards the rich over the poor, for they are all the work of his hands.
verses.comment: God’s impartiality foreshadows New Testament teaching of the unity of all believers before God (Gal. 3:28).

verses.text: They die in a moment. In the middle of the night, the people are shaken and pass away; the mighty are taken away, not by human hands.
verses.comment: The suddenness of death for all, regardless of status, reminds readers of the fleeting nature of earthly glory (see James 4:14).

verses.text: For his eyes are on the ways of a man, and he sees all his steps.
verses.comment: God’s omniscience means nothing is hidden from Him—a theme echoed throughout Scripture (Heb. 4:13).

verses.text: There is no darkness, no deep shadow, where evildoers may hide themselves.
verses.comment: Not even darkness can hide from God, paralleling the light imagery of Christ in John 1.

verses.text: For God has no need to examine a man further, that he should go before God in judgment.
verses.comment: God requires no further evidence—His knowledge is complete, anticipating the last judgment described in Rev. 20:12.

verses.text: He shatters the mighty without investigation, and sets others in their place.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes God's sovereignty to raise up and remove rulers—a doctrine present in both Testaments.

verses.text: Thus, he knows their deeds; he overturns them in the night, and they are crushed.
verses.comment: The suddenness of God's judgment reinforces that human power is fleeting before divine authority.

verses.text: He strikes them as wicked men in a public place,
verses.comment: Public judgment echoes prophetic warnings and the idea that ultimately, justice is manifested before all.

verses.text: Because they turned aside from following him and had no regard for any of his ways,
verses.comment: Refers to the sin of abandoning God, a charge common throughout Israel’s history and pointing to the necessity of faithfulness.

verses.text: So that they cause the cry of the poor to come before him, and he hears the cry of the afflicted.
verses.comment: God’s concern for the poor and afflicted is consistent throughout Scripture (Luke 4:18).

verses.text: When he is silent, who can condemn? When he hides his face, who can behold him? Yet he is over both nation and man alike,
verses.comment: God’s mysterious ways are sometimes hidden, inviting humble trust. The universality of his governance foreshadows the kingdom imagery applied to Christ.

verses.text: so that godless men should not rule lest the people be ensnared.
verses.comment: God’s righteous rule prevents the tyranny of the wicked, a central hope reflected in the prayer, 'Your kingdom come' (Matt. 6:10).

verses.text: For has anyone said to God, 'I have borne chastisement; I will not offend any more;
verses.comment: Repentance and confession are key themes here, pointing forward to the sacramental practice of reconciliation found throughout both Testaments.

verses.text: Teach me what I cannot see; if I have done wrong, I will do it no more'?
verses.comment: A humble request for God’s guidance and forgiveness foreshadows Christian themes of metanoia (change of heart).

verses.text: Should God repay on your terms, since you refuse to accept his judgment? You must choose, and not I; therefore, speak what you know.
verses.comment: Elihu warns against demanding God conform to human expectations, inviting trust in his providence.

verses.text: Men of understanding will say to me, and the wise man who hears me will say:
verses.comment: Reiterates the value of wisdom and the consensus of the wise—a theme developed in Judeo-Christian tradition.

verses.text: 'Job speaks without knowledge, and his words are without understanding.'
verses.comment: Elihu judges Job's speech as lacking wisdom, anticipating God's own response.

verses.text: 'Would that Job were tested to the end, because he answers like wicked men!
verses.comment: A plea for Job to be tested—a theme that resonates with the New Testament idea of trials refining faith (1 Pet. 1:7).

verses.text: For he adds rebellion to his sin; he claps his hands among us and multiplies his words against God.'"
verses.comment: Elihu concludes by asserting that Job’s objections border on rebellion, warning against self-justification before God.
